comment.author: 61077563@N00
comment._content:
Fantastic example of the Indo-Saracenic style, no doubt hitherto forgotten. In Australia there was a sudden burst of buildings built in this style around 1890. Could this have been the main impetus?
Does anyone know what happened to this complex?

comment.author: 87592669@N00
comment._content: I attended the 1988 Glasgow Garden Festival...very modern architecture.  1888 looks nicer!

comment.author: 18007377@N08
comment._content:
Absolutely astounding photography given the time frame. This is pure talent at it's very best. Such fabulous composition and exposure.
My family was from Glasgow and the majority of the images I have of their home, where created from green glass type negatives they brought over with them.  Nothing nearly as impressive, but I am still thankful to have them.   So nice to be able to view these on Flickr.

comment._content: What a very impressive building....why don't they make them like this anymore?

comment.author: 55102848@N00
comment._content: Fantastic image of an important point in Glasgow's rise to becoming the Second City of the Empire I believe it was taken at the bridge at Kelvin Way, or maybe slightly upstream from that point (near the first bridge across the Kelvin within the park?), the building you are looking at is the principal building of the 1888 exhibition, the profits of which funded the building of the current Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum and the 1901 exhibition. There may be a past / present at either www.hiddenglasgow.com or at www.urbanglasgow.com - However I may just pop down the road later and take one myself if the weather improves

comment.author: 32643530@N03
comment._content: This is a guess, but for those who have Google Earth I've created a Google Earth kmz file which guesses the location: www.bigfeartie.com/ExhibitionPictureSourceLocation.zip It's zipped up....it's very small anyway. Sorry didn't know a way of making the file available on flickr. I'm assuming the bridge is the one on Google Earth and the image is not reversed...

comment.author: 36501969@N00
comment._content: yes, i think the domed building on the left of shot is now the bowling greens. Photo is taken from where the east end of the footbridge is now. maps.google.co.uk/?ie=UTF8&ll=55.868142,-4.287339&...

comment.author: 55102848@N00
comment._content:
The bridge in the photo isn't the current Kelvin Way bridge. The 1888 festival had 2 bridges crossing the Kelvin, the first was just downstream of the Kelvin Way and the other a little further downstream. The building ran from the Cameronians Memorial all the way to Gray Street, making it several times larger than the current museum building.

The location of the photo is indeed around the location of the modern footbridge which leads from Kelvin Way to Stewart Memorial Fountain. 

btw the Doulton fountain outside the People's Palace started off its life at the 1888 festival and was just round the bend in the photo.

comment.author: 28394738@N04
comment._content: Mystical... Fantastic. Thanks for sharing.

comment.author: 51422514@N00
comment._content:
The inside of the building was just as impressive.  There are some books about the exhibitions (I found one in Langside library) with photos of this building and others from the 1888 exhibition.  Inside it was just as elaborate and I believe it was the industrial exhibition building with stands from different companies in Britain and throughout the Empire.

Amazing that they built such 'temporary' buildings back then.  Pity that, unlike the Eiffel Tower, it didn't become permanent.
